title: Wednesday, 7th November 2018

BE11:21am

The Democrats won back control of the House of Representatives while the
Republicans strengthened their grip on the Senate. A split Congress was very
much the base case and the one discounted by the equity markets in our
view. Hence, the bond and currency markets were little changed post the
result. Looking forward, infrastructure investment, a theme championed by
both parties, might be back on the agenda.
Consensus had expected an 85% chance of GOP keeping the Senate and an 85%
chance of Democrats taking the House. Hence, it would have needed a very
dramatic shift to have shaken up the equity markets. The markets will probably
feel that the current tax cuts and regulatory changes will be maintained while
the influence of one Democratic chamber will act as a check and balance on the
Executive Branch. Furthermore, there will be no further tax cuts while the Fed
is unlikely to be distracted from the path of one further hike in December.
In a dispassionate way the equity markets probably got the outcome they
wanted. The concern that an emboldened Republican party retaining both
houses might have embraced another round of tax cuts, thereby increasing the
deficit, has receded. Meanwhile, the worry was that if the Democrats had won
back both houses, the tax cuts and regulatory changes might have been rolled
back or rescinded.

A. M. (@Pharma -- every two years? I thought it was four-years, staggered. oops.)

Pharma @TonaldDrump - oh, assumed he would be. Must go check, although it does nothing for my level of sympathy.@AM, yup, house of representatives changes en mass envery 2 years. Senators get 6 years (so only a third get elected in each cycle)
casapinos @BE ..."or at any other time?....."

11:23 am
BE11:23am

What to look out for? Looking forward Special Counsel Robert Mueller will likely present
his findings to Deputy Attorney Rod Rosenstein over whether the President conspired with
Russia in influencing the 2016 elections. Impeachment concerns are probably overdone.
Nevertheless, the confrontational atmosphere between the two parties is unlikely to help sentiment. There is a growing likelihood of a reshuffle of the Trump administration. The G20 summit takes center stage in Buenos Aires on 30 November & 1 December with potential
US Presidential meetings with Russian President Putin and Chinese President Xi Jinping. Then
there is the not too small matter of the US presidential elections in 2020.
And what about the markets? We have had a number of questions about the level of US
real rates that the equity market can survive. With nominal GDP well above ten-year rates,
investors generally felt that a real rate close to 1% was quite bearable. We would concur;
however, a real rate at 2% has historically suffocated equity performance. Don’t short the S&P 500.

BE11:28am

We reduce our billings growth forecasts to 4% for H2 and 12% for 2020. We downgrade our rating on the shares to Neutral (previously Overweight), as we struggle to see opportunity for positive momentum in the near term, and now need to see sequential evidence of stronger billings delivery before we could think about turning more constructive. We also reduce our price target to 420p (previously 600p).

Here's how they interpreted management's vague stuff.

BE11:29am

Sophos has guided to “modest improvement in cc billings growth in H219 compared to the first half”, which we read as 5% or lower (vs. consensus ~12%). For 2020, the company anticipates "a significant improvement in the rate of cc billings growth", which leaves a wide range for interpretation, but perhaps 10%+ (vs. consensus of 16%).

BE11:29am

Model changes: We have reduced our billings estimates by 7% for FY19
and 12% for 2020, while our Cash EBITDA estimates are down by 10% and
14%, respectively. We are now modelling FY19 billings of $769m, cc
growth of 3%, and $869m for 2020, growth of 12%. Revenue forecasts are
more modestly impacted, given the deferred revenue flow-through from
previous billings. Cash EBITDA is reduced by 8% to $206m for FY19E and
by 13% for FY20E to $252m. We reduce our Mar-19 PT to 420p to reflect a
reduction in our estimates, as well as reduced confidence in the company’s
ability to meet guidance.

A. M. @Pharma: certain privatised utilities come to mind.
qwerty Sophos. Good use of spin doctor! Billings in line with expectations; strong revenue, profit and cash performance. Shares down 25%+!

Sophos softened its tone for mid-teens billings growth in 2H19e and
expects a modest constant currency YoY growth rate (2-5% growth). For FY20e,
Sophos anticipates a significant improvement in billings growth, which we interpret
to suggest a mid-teens rate. The lowered guidance infers FY20e billings between
$907-921 million (vs. consensus at $971 million). We estimate that the raw drop
through suggests FY20e uFCF between $137-152 million, 25-31% below the $201
million consensus average (and below $220-240 million guidance). However, we anticipate that cost measures will provide some remedy for the shortfall.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

Against that you have longstanding concerns about Sophos's preferred measures of earnings and its ability to turn bookings into cashflow.

BE11:33am

You can, however, make a buy case down at these levels. Morgan Stanley does.

BE11:33am

Sophos reported a disappointing set of FY2Q results and lowered its 2H outlook.
This is likely, we think, to lead to cuts of 4%/5% to billings in FY19 and FY20 for
the street. The cuts to bottom line for the street may be higher – but we would
not expect materially greater than 10%. The shares are now trading at 305p, -34%. We try to
find value in software in times of stress using EV/recurring metrics. Below 4x has
almost always been a good time to buy traditional software stocks. We do find
lower troughs for subscription software companies (2-3x), but these have tended
to be loss-making businesses. At 305p, Sophos is trading at 2.5x EV/subscription
billings and 3x EV/subscription sales (our best proxy for recurring sales at Sophos). We have seen the stock trough at these types of levels before, in 2016. Once again, at these levels we see a very attractive buying opportunity and would remain buyers here.

BE11:37am

And like Sophos, it's a management credibility story as much as a downgrade story.

BE11:37am

Here's RBC.

BE11:37am

The group is now guiding to flat CC
profits in 2018, which is slightly ambiguous but we think means EBITA of c£468m vs current consensus of £480m so a 2.5% miss. This reflects the lower revenues and continued investment in technology. On the positive side, the group has announced a Cash360 contract win (600 stores in US) and believes the strong pipeline will provide good revenue momentum into 2019. Clearly the stock has been weak (2yr rel low) and the valuation looks undemanding (19E PE 11x, FCF Yield 8% and div yield 5%), but the key issue with this stock is trust and this statement does nothing to help that. Given the CEO has been there for c.5 years and has not created any value, we wonder whether it is time for something more radical. We believe a sale or demerger of part or all of Cash Services and/or Justice Services would achieve the goals of focus and debt reduction as well as freeing up management time to focus on the core Security Solutions and Technology businesses.

Mouselet I can't help feeling that the bankruptcy of the middleman providing health care to half the councils in England would be questions-in-the-House levels of bad
11:37 am
BE11:37am

We continue to believe G4S has a strong market position in an industry with some structural drivers and enjoys a competitive advantage from its ability to
integrate services and from its technology capabilities. We see organic growth potential in the 4-6% range in the medium term, with margin improvements (+10-
15bp pa) from mix and productivity improvements, with refinancing of expensive debt also helping EPS growth. Cashflow should also benefit from further WC
improvements and onerous contracts dropping out. We also believe management actions are improving the overall quality of the business mix and see the degearing
of the balance sheet as a further positive. Valuation looks attractive versus the sector and peers and we see the stock as one of few with a genuine
rerating opportunity if it can deliver. However, delivery has been an issue and until EPS momentum changes and the group can deliver on expectations, we think
it is tough for the market to give the benefit of the doubt in the short term.

Big Red G4S, not sure "cash handling" ought to be considered anything more than a sunset business

BE11:39am

We believe the market's confidence in management's promises has been dented by yet another underwhelming update. The group is developing a reputation for over-promising / under-delivering; it will take time to rebuild trust.

BE11:39am

In the meantime we expect the shares to tread water. G4S has strong foundations operationally but so far has failed to translate these to sustained earnings
momentum. This needs to change if the share price is to regain some positive momentum.
We downgrade to HOLD and cut our FY18 earnings numbers by c.7% (consensus likely
to come down by c.3-4%). Our new 190p target price represents 10x 12-month forward earnings, at the bottom end of the group's trading range [11-18x] and represents a dividend yield of c.5% which we think is sensible.

Assume you saw the stuff in the Sundays confirming that M&S looked at hiving off the food business but deciding it wouldn't work. Archaeology, of course, but interesting.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Most brokers here are sellers, such as Caz.

BE11:48am

Overall this is a better than expected first half performance from MKS, with a headline 10% beat on PBT,
although in our view, we think the results more broadly are mixed. First the positives: headline 10% beat on
PBT supported by a better than expected Food gross margin (as MKS has moved away from profit dilutive
promotions) and opex phasing (costs -2.1% yoy vs. JPMe -0.8%); broadly in-line C&H performance including
Clothing online growth in double digit territory; store estate closure and medium term opex savings plans on
track; and capex guidance has been reduced. However, less positively: Food LFL is a miss at -2.9% (cons. -
2.0%) and management’s tone on the speed of improvement in this business, and scale of changes necessary to
drive such improvement is not encouraging (for example “longer term progress will require more far reaching
restructuring of the supply chain”); on LFL sales across both businesses, management is expecting “little
improvement in sales trajectory” over the remainder of the year; opex guidance for the full year is unchanged
and with the H1 profit beat driven largely by phasing, if anything our first take is that, combined with sales
commentary, FY PBT forecasts could nudge slightly lower. Whilst the shares have been resilient, and full year
numbers could nudge lower, the short interest remains high (at c.21%), and hence we would expect the shares to
open higher first thing. However, as a first take there is little here to change our structurally negative view and
hence we would be selling into any strength.

Gross Loydman Anything on Flybe? It's strongly up today on large volume. Technical bounce or something more substantial...?
Soundbuy @ casapinos - outside London and a few larger cities.........no
BE11:49am

And Macquarie.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

In our view, M&S remains structurally challenged and it scores poorly in our
strategic fashion framework. Management is tackling key issues and has initiated good cost savings. However, in our view more aggressive investments will come, while there is no guarantee of success in a market which is changing fast, potentially faster than it takes to transform M&S. At the same time, competition is intensifying. We stay Underperform.

BE11:50am

The smaller things to pick on in the statement include that technology and supply chain remain problematic.

BE11:50am

And international revenue was down 19.1%

Mouselet (in Watford because Watford Junction is where the shuttle bus to Harry Potter World Leavesden goes from ... I am a cynical wossname but actually the Aladdin's-Cave aspect of Harry Potter World, which is basically a well-laid-out props warehouse with explanatory text and friendly guides, is an awful lot of fun)
BE11:52am

Geoff Ruddell at Morgan Stanley incoming.

BE11:52am

Although disappointing, we think downgrades on this scale pose minimal risk to
the dividend (which has been maintained in FYH1), and it remains very well
supported by cash flows (the group generated free cash flow of £241m in FYH1
vs £105m in the prior year and is on course, on our analysis, to pay down more
than £200m of debt this year as well as fund its dividend).
- Overall we think this statement paints a picture of a group undergoing radical,
and very rapid, change but where this change is yet to feed through into
improved trading performance. However, with the shares yielding a (very secure)
6.3%, we think shareholders are being well remunerated for their patience.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Based on existing consensus forecasts and last night's closing share price, M&S
is trading on 11.2x calendar 2019 earnings, 5.5x EBITDA with a 6.3% dividend yield. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 12.0x, 7.8x and 4.0%,
respectively.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

[T]he news is indeed bad, with sales collapsing and a big £2.1m write-off. And current trading is challenging, with UK LFL Retail sales down by 7% over the last 6 weeks and all the company can promise is that there will be an underlying profit of some sort for the full year (the H1 loss increased from £0.6m to £3.6m).

MassimoJ @BE, I still think the church pews are the best setting for sourdough pizza. Could be my only bit of 2008 nostalgia though
BE12:02pm

But, no disaster. And bear in mind there's very little free float in this thing. Cantor:

BE12:02pm

Mulberry's interim results for the six months ended 30 September 2018 show total revenues decreased by 8% to £68.3m with International Retail sales up 13%, UK Retail sales down 11% and Global Digital Retail sales up 5%. Underlying loss before tax was £3.6m before £4.6m of exceptional costs including House of Fraser concession-related impacts of £2.1m. Net cash at the end of the period was £12,1m, a £4.3m decrease from £16.3m last year. Current trading shows UK Retail LFLs down 7% in the six weeks to 3 November. The Group anticipates underlying profit before tax for the year to March 2019 despite a challenging first half.

BE12:12pm

9M figures as expected but expect consensus downgrades for a weaker suggested 4Q in TV and Studios and new management investment/property cost but the latter
may be already in some forecasts: our FY18/19E EPS is -6%/-10% and multiples
based PT to 175p (190p before). While we are likely to see some share weakness
today, our Add reflects modest valuation and strategic value in ITV Studios, though
we do see Broadcast TV ad revenues (FY c. £1.5bn) as under pressure. The key to rerating would be increased confidence in the new CEO plan to build non Broadcast
revenues, though execution remains uncertain, especially over launch of a UK
streaming service. Brexit is unhelpful for UK ad sentiment and we note 4Q ad comment.

BE12:12pm

[W]e now assume total advertising flat in FY18/19E (+1% before) and allow
for Studios timing plus ‘catch up’ extra new premises costs and investment post the
late summer CMD; this gives adj FD EPS 14.6p/13.9p (was 15.5p/15.5p) vs previous
Reuters consensus 15.3p/15p. We estimate new underlying downgrades at roughly
half of these figures and half is extra costs we knew about. We have not included any
new streaming investment or revenues and await further detail on any planned launch.

12:12 pm
